title: Epigenetics in Neurological Disease
description: Examine how heritable changes in gene expression — independent of DNA sequence — shape brain development and contribute to neurological and psychiatric disorders.
learningObjectives: Define epigenetics and distinguish it from sequence-level genetic variation
Explain the mechanism and gene-regulatory consequences of DNA methylation
Describe histone modifications and how they collectively shape chromatin state
Understand the role of ATP-dependent chromatin remodeling complexes
Connect specific epigenetic dysregulation to Rett syndrome, Fragile X, and Alzheimer's disease

sections.title: What Is Epigenetics?
sections.content: Epigenetics refers to heritable changes in gene expression and chromatin structure that occur without alterations to the underlying DNA sequence. Epigenetic mechanisms serve as the molecular interface between an organism's static genome and a dynamic environment, allowing context-dependent gene regulation across development, aging, and in response to experience.
keyPoints: Epigenetic changes can be mitotically stable — transmitted to daughter cells during cell division
Many epigenetic marks are reversible, making them attractive targets for therapeutic intervention
The brain epigenome is extraordinarily dynamic; it changes throughout development, in response to neural activity, and with aging
Four major mechanisms: DNA methylation, histone modifications, chromatin remodeling, and non-coding RNA regulation

sections.title: DNA Methylation
sections.content: DNA methylation involves the covalent addition of a methyl group (−CH₃) to the 5-carbon of cytosine residues, predominantly at CpG dinucleotides. This modification is catalyzed by DNA methyltransferases (DNMTs) and is the most extensively characterized epigenetic mark in mammals.
keyPoints: CpG islands: regions of elevated CpG density found at ~70% of gene promoters; normally unmethylated to permit active transcription
Promoter hypermethylation recruits methyl-binding proteins and HDACs → condensed chromatin → transcriptional silencing
DNMT3A/3B establish de novo methylation patterns; DNMT1 (the 'maintenance methyltransferase') propagates them through replication
TET enzymes (TET1-3) oxidize 5-methylcytosine, initiating active demethylation; highly expressed in neurons, critical for plasticity

sections.title: Histone Modifications and the Histone Code
sections.content: Genomic DNA is packaged by wrapping ~147 base pairs around a histone octamer (H2A, H2B, H3, H4) to form the nucleosome — the fundamental repeating unit of chromatin. The unstructured N-terminal tails of histones are subject to more than 100 known post-translational modifications that together form a combinatorial 'histone code' governing gene expression.
keyPoints: Acetylation (HATs add; HDACs remove): neutralizes the positive charge of lysine, loosens DNA-histone interaction → open chromatin, active transcription
H3K4me3: trimethylation of histone H3 lysine 4 — marks active gene promoters
H3K27me3: Polycomb-mediated mark associated with stable gene repression and developmental silencing
H3K9me3: heterochromatic mark associated with constitutive gene silencing; enriched at repetitive elements

sections.title: Chromatin Remodeling Complexes
sections.content: ATP-dependent chromatin remodeling complexes use ATP hydrolysis to slide, eject, or restructure nucleosomes, altering the physical accessibility of DNA to transcription factors and the transcriptional machinery. They are among the most frequently mutated gene families in neurodevelopmental disorders.
keyPoints: Four major families: SWI/SNF (BAF in mammals), ISWI, CHD, and INO80 — each with distinct mechanisms and genomic targets
BAF complex (mammalian SWI/SNF): essential for neural differentiation; ARID1B and SMARCC2 mutations cause Coffin-Siris syndrome / intellectual disability
CHD7 mutations cause CHARGE syndrome (coloboma, heart defects, choanal atresia, growth retardation, genital and ear abnormalities)
CHD8: one of the highest-confidence autism risk genes; haploinsufficiency disrupts genome-wide gene expression in neural progenitors

sections.title: Epigenetic Dysregulation in Brain Disorders
sections.content: A rapidly growing list of neurological and neuropsychiatric conditions are caused by mutations in epigenetic regulators or characterized by disease-associated epigenomic changes. Understanding these mechanisms reveals disease pathology and points toward novel therapeutic strategies.
keyPoints: Rett Syndrome: MECP2 loss-of-function mutations disrupt methyl-CpG binding and co-repressor recruitment; primarily affects girls; causes progressive neurological regression
Fragile X Syndrome: CGG repeat expansion (>200 repeats) in FMR1 5' UTR triggers promoter hypermethylation and silencing of FMRP, an RNA-binding protein essential for synaptic plasticity
Alzheimer's Disease: global DNA hypomethylation combined with locus-specific hypermethylation; reduced H4K16ac near APP and PSEN1; HDAC inhibitors under investigation
Therapeutic frontier: HDAC inhibitors (e.g., valproate), DNMT inhibitors, and emerging CRISPR-based epigenome editors are being explored in clinical trials

quiz.question: Which statement best defines an epigenetic change?
options: A permanent alteration in the DNA nucleotide sequence passed to offspring
A heritable change in gene expression or chromatin structure without altering the DNA sequence
A change in mRNA stability caused by RNA-binding proteins
A somatic point mutation affecting a single cell
quiz.explanation: Epigenetic changes are heritable modifications to gene expression or chromatin organization that do not change the underlying DNA sequence. They include DNA methylation, histone modifications, and chromatin remodeling — all reversible and context-dependent.

quiz.question: Hypermethylation of a gene's promoter CpG island most commonly results in:
options: Enhanced RNA polymerase II recruitment and increased transcription
Increased histone acetylation and an open chromatin state
Transcriptional silencing of the associated gene
Alternative splicing of the downstream mRNA transcript
quiz.explanation: Promoter CpG island hypermethylation recruits methyl-CpG binding proteins and histone deacetylases, which compact chromatin into a transcriptionally repressive state, effectively silencing the gene.

quiz.question: Which histone modification is most strongly associated with actively transcribed gene promoters?
options: H3K27me3 (Polycomb-mediated repression)
H3K9me3 (heterochromatic silencing)
H3K4me3 (active promoter mark)
H2AK119ub1 (Polycomb-mediated silencing)
quiz.explanation: H3K4me3 — trimethylation of lysine 4 on histone H3 — is a hallmark of active gene promoters and correlates with open chromatin and robust transcription. H3K27me3 and H3K9me3 are repressive marks.

quiz.question: Rett Syndrome is caused by MECP2 loss-of-function mutations. What is the normal molecular function of MECP2?
options: It methylates cytosine residues at CpG sites as a de novo DNA methyltransferase
It binds methylated CpG dinucleotides and recruits co-repressor complexes to silence genes
It demethylates histone H3K27me3 marks as a histone demethylase
It slides nucleosomes along DNA by hydrolyzing ATP
quiz.explanation: MECP2 is a methyl-CpG binding protein — a 'reader' of DNA methylation. It binds to methylated CpG dinucleotides and recruits co-repressor complexes (including Sin3A and HDACs) to silence target genes. Loss of MECP2 in Rett syndrome leads to widespread transcriptional dysregulation throughout the brain.

quiz.question: In Fragile X Syndrome, a CGG repeat expansion in the FMR1 gene leads to disease by:
options: Hypomethylation of the FMR1 promoter, causing toxic overexpression of FMRP
A frameshift mutation that truncates the FMRP protein
Hypermethylation of the FMR1 promoter, silencing FMR1 expression
Deletion of the FMR1 gene through large-scale chromosomal rearrangement
quiz.explanation: When the CGG repeat in the FMR1 5' UTR expands beyond ~200 copies (full mutation), it triggers dense DNA methylation of the FMR1 promoter, completely silencing the gene. Loss of FMRP — an mRNA-binding protein critical for synaptic plasticity — is the molecular basis of Fragile X Syndrome.
